coredata.dc:title: The field far from a charge and a dipole
coredata.dc:creator: Keyes, T.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We consider the field far from charged and dipolar impurities in a fluid of polarizable non-polar atoms. Comparison with a recent computer simulation shows that classical continuum ideas are adequate for a charge, but not for a non-polarizable dipole; we present a very simple theory which agrees well with the simulation in that case. No simulation exists for a polarizable dipole, which we also discuss.

The MD data of PAP show, in light of these ideas that: (a) The Maxwell field far from a charge is given by classical continuum theory. (b) If the Lorentz local field is allowed, the local field far from a charge is given by classical continuum theory. (c) The fields far from a non-polarizable dipole are not given by classical continuum theory. They are predicted, however, by an extremely simple theory which requires no subtle information about the fluid. (d) The idea that the field far from a dipole has as an upper bound that from a polarizable dipole and as a lower bound that from a non-polarizable dipole in the continuum approximation is very instructive.
